title: Times New Roman for Logo
content:
Hi all,

I stumbled upon this great forum.  
I am designing my logo with a Times New Roman typeface. I really like it and I don’t want to modify it.

Does anyone know if I would run into any copyright infringement if I leave it as is?

Here is a pic attached.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090624020504im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo_5565.png)
author: pulgo

comments.content: If your question is whether you can use Times New Roman for your logo, there should be no problem; the thing to check is the End-User License Agreement ( [EULA](http://web.archive.org/web/20090624020504/http:/typophile.com/wiki/EULA)), but there may not be a clear one if this is the version bundled with an operating system. Regardless, it is a valid use of a font to use it in a logo—otherwise, purchasing a font wouldn’t be very worthwhile. There are sometimes limitations (e.g. you may not embed the font in a PDF, you may not use it in a video game without prior permission, etc.). If your question is about something else, such as the name or appearance, that I don’t know.

Yes, but the EULA issue isn’t going to affect you, if what you’re doing is using it to create a logo, then delivering the logo as vector art (or other image file.)

Assuming you have the rights to use the font, then you can use it to create a logo/wordmark. then you can distribute the wordmark as an image file with no licensing issues.

The issue would only come into play if you’re going to do some sort of template design or similar, where you supply a use of the typeface, then each user would have to have the font licensed for themselves.

Similarly, you can use the font to create an image, then alter that image in any way you like. Say, you type out “MiMo” in TNR, then convert to vector shapes, then delete some of the serifs, and distribute the image file. That is a fine use of the type.

What you can’t do is open TNR in Fontlab, delete some serifs, save as a font called Times for MiMo, and distribute the font (unless the EULA allows that.)

Jason C

Ahhh, that explains a lot!

Yes, I only want it for my logo as you see it on the image, nothing else.  
And since I have no symbol / graphic / drawing etc. as a “logo” but  
only the name written with Times New Roman, I was wondering if this is illegal.

Thanks a lot for your time, AuricFuzz and Jason, I really appreciate it.
